question:
Which of the texts describes the DFM schema below?
Immagine senza didascalia
We need to track the purchases with credit cards. Each purchase has an amount, an exchange and a credit limit. The purchases are done in a date and i a store of a given type and country; stores have also an area. Purchasees have a card name (e.g. MyCard or JeansCard), card_names have a card type (e.g. credit or debit). Card types have also an issuing bank adnd a country.

answers.text: We need to track the purchases with credit cards. Each puchase has an amount, an exchange and a credit limit. The purchases are done in a date and in a store of a given type; stores types have also a country and an area. Purchases have a card type (e.g. credit or debit) and a card name (e.g. MyCard or JeansCard). Card names have also ain issuing bank and a country.

We need to track the purchases with credit cards. Each purchase has an amount, an exchange and a credit limit. The purchases are done in a date and in a store of a given type; stores have also a country and an area. Purchases have a card type (e.g. credit or debit) and a card name (e.g. MyCard or JeansCard). Card types have also an issuing bank and a country.

question: Which of the definition below describes the OLAP operation Drill-Down

answers.text: Changes the layout, in order to analyse a group of data from a different viewpoint
Reduces the number of cube dimensions after setting one of the dimensions to a specific value
Creates a link between concepts in interrelated cubes, to compare them
Causes an increase in data aggregation and removes a detail level in a hierarchy
Reduces data aggregation and adds a detail level to a hierarchy

question: Select the sentences describing a characteristic of a Data Warehouse

answers.text: Includes all the base data in their native format
Non volatile
Includes the time dimension
Solves the inconsistencies
Constantly updated as soon as the base data are updated

question: Which of the definition below describes the OLAP operation Pivot

answers.text: Reduces data aggregation and adds a detail level to a hierarchy
Causes an increase in data aggregation and removes a detail level in a hierarchy
Creates a link between concepts in interrelated cubes, to compare them
Reduces the number of cube dimensions after setting one of the dimensions to a specific value
Changes the layout, in order to analyse a group of data from a different viewpoint

question: Check the features of Data Lakes in comparison with Data Warehouses, Multiple answers allowed. Selecting a wrong option will be penalised

answers.text: Can run on less expensive HW/SW
Do not enforce data quality
More complex management
Completely defined use cases

question: Talking about the general idea of database, what is the purpose of the "Schema on write" strategy?

answers.text: Optimisation for specific types of queries
Clean design of the data structure
Avoid preprocessing of data before writing
Flexibility and efficiency for any kind of query

question: Talking about the general idea of database, what is the meaning of "Schema on read"?

answers.text: Create a schema for data after reading them from the database
Write the raw data in the database, then at reading time shape then according to the reader's needs
Change the schema of the data before each read
Read the schema of the data before each data read

question: Which of the following are typical data warehouse queries?

answers.text: What is the total revenue of yesterday in shop "BO03"?
What is the total revenue per product category and state?
Which products maximize the profit?
What is the relationship between profits gained by products "WWW" and "ZZZ"?
Which is the stock of product "XXX" in the "YYY" warehouse

question: Which of the following sentences describes an advantage of a Data Warehouse with respect to a standard DBMS

answers.text: Has tools for helping to solve inconsistencies
Allows efficient execution of key-based queries
Allows efficient execution of multi-dimensional queries
Manages efficiently data updates
Allows analysis along the time dimension

question: Talking about the general idea of database, what is the meaning of "Schema on write"?

answers.text: Create a schema for data while writing into the database
Create a schema for data before writing into the database
Change the schema of the data after each write

question: Check the main objectives pursued when choosing a Data Lake architecture

answers.text: Store the data directly from the sources, as they are; the most appropriate structure will be decided later, according to the user needs
The data must be accurately structured, in order to provide fast answers to complex queries
The storage must be scalable and cheap, at the expenses of latency
Ensure high quality of data through an accurate cleaning and transformation step

answers.text: Association of a timestamp to the operational data
Elimination of duplicates
Snapshot of the operational data
Usage of dictionaries to solve inconsistencies

question: What is Data Ingestion?

answers.text: A process that copies data from sources to a repository, taking care of possible differences in speed between the generation and the storing process
A process that copies data from sources to a repository, ensuring high data quality
A process that copies data from sources to a repository, making the transformation required by the user
A process that copies data from sources to a Data Warehouse guaranteeing the correctness of data with respect to the schema

question: Which of the activities below is part of "Business Understanding" in the CRISP methodology?

answers.text: Which machine learning functions are necessary for my problem?
Which data must be collected with a specific campaign?
Which data are available?
Which are the resources available (manpower, hardware, software, ...)

answers.text: Possibility to extract data in various shapes
Optimisation for various types of queries
Flexibility for any kind of query
Avoid preprocessing of data before writing
